title.narrative: Driving a conducive cocoa sector in the Netherlands

description.narrative: Influence policies through existing networks, including promoting the development of viable alternatives to the existing certification system resulting in a new generation of sustainability initiatives that generate a living income for cocoa farmers, and advocating for inclusive supply chains through the strengthening of the Women in Cocoa and Chocolate Network (WINCC) to address gender inequalities and farm level and throughout the supply chain. Main focus in 2019 was supporting the call for a living income for Cocoa farmers. Joint advocacy efforts of Solidaridad and others focusing on the position of smallholder cocoa farmers and the role of national governments, contributed to the establishment of a living income price differential in the by the Ghana and Ivory Coast governments. Companies and industry organizations followed suit and announced to pay the Ghana/CDI living income differential. Solidaridad participated in two CSO networks to jointly address the issues and recommendations of the 2018 Barometer: the VOICE network and the Barometer consortium. Together with VOICE Network, Solidaridad advocated for a living wage for cocoa farmers. As a result RA/UTZ announced a mandatory cash premium to be implemented in the near future. We joined the Dutch Initiative on Sustainable Cocoa (DISCO) to negotiate an ambitious and credible charter for the Dutch cocoa sector. Our lobby of the private sector starts to pay off: Barry Callebaut, Tony’s, Mars, Mondelez, Hershey, Cargill, Olam and Nestle show increasing commitments of varying levels with training, living incomes, child-labour free supply chains and greater forest protection.

title.narrative: CSOs mobilize companies to adopt sustainable policies
# of recommendations of (local) stakeholders and CSOs included in the dialogue

description.narrative: # issues raised by Solidaridad and partners that are included in outcome of MSP dialogues / policy discussions

comment.narrative: # issues raised by Solidaridad and partners that are included in outcome of MSP dialogues / policy discussions

1) living income, 2) transparency & accountability, and 3) certification
As part of the Cocoa Barometer consortium, Solidaridad worked on the development of the Cocoa Barometer. Specifically, we have contributed to the development of two consultation papers on living wage and transparency and accountability. In these papers, we analysed the current situation and provided recommendations to stakeholders on their role in the solution. The papers have been published by the consortium partners via their own media channels as well as through sector news outlets such as Confectionery News. In addition, it has been promoted at several cocoa conferences. Feedback on the papers was collected, which serves as input for the further development of the Barometer. The goal of the barometer is to raise awareness on key bottlenecks in the development of a sustainable cocoa sector and to mobilise brands, standard setters and governments to implement the recommendations made. Unfortunately, due to a delay on the side of the contracted party that would deliver the content, the publication of the Barometer had to be postponed to 2018.

title.narrative: National government bodies improve policies to promote more sustainable practice
# + kind of improved mechanisms, policies and regulations of national government

comment.narrative: Joint advocacy efforts of Solidaridad and others focusing on the position of smallholder cocoa farmers and the role of national governments, contributed to the establishment of a living income price differential in the course of 2019 by the governments of Ghana and Ivory Coast. Companies and industry organizations announced to pay the Ghana/CDI living income differential. Together with the VOICE network, Solidaridad advocated for a living wage for cocoa farmers. As a result RA/UTZ announced a mandatory cash premium to be implemented in the near future.
